  "article_text": [
    "a _ word series _",
    "@xcite is a formal linear combination , usually infinite : @xmath0 where @xmath1 is a set , called alphabet , and @xmath2 is the free ( associative ) monoid of words @xmath3 generated by the letters from @xmath1 .",
    "the map @xmath4 is a monoid morphism from @xmath2 into a unital associative algebra @xmath5 over some base field @xmath6 .",
    "we have to assume that @xmath5 is endowed with a topology such that the infinite sum is convergent .",
    "the coefficients @xmath7 belong to the base field @xmath6 or to some unital commutative algebra @xmath8 such that @xmath5 is an @xmath8-algebra .",
    "the collection @xmath9 is called a _ mould _ in @xcite , whereas the collection @xmath10 is called a _ comould _ , and the word series is the _ _ mould - comould contraction _ _",
    "is chosen to be a monoid antimorphism in @xcite . ] .",
    "we will stick to the case where the comould @xmath11 is tautological , namely @xmath12 .",
    "this makes sense with @xmath13 being the algebra of noncommutative power series with variables in @xmath1 .",
    "mould calculus _ has been developed by j.  ecalle in @xcite , as a powerful tool in studying formal or analytic local objects ( vector fields or diffeomorphisms ) around the origin in @xmath14 . in most of the situations",
    "encountered , the alphabet @xmath1 is a commutative semigroup , typically the positive integers , @xmath15 or @xmath16 . in this case ,",
    "two associative products are available on the vector space of moulds : the _ mould product _ @xmath17 and the _ mould composition _",
    "the definition of the latter involves the semigroup structure of @xmath1 in an essential way ( see the definitions in section [ sect : moules ] ) .",
    "+ the algebra @xmath19 is the dual of the coalgebra @xmath20 of noncommutative polynomials with variables in @xmath1 , endowed with the deconcatenation coproduct : @xmath21 moreover , a mould gives rise , by linear extension , to a unique linear form on @xmath20 .",
    "the identification of the vector space of moulds with @xmath19 is achieved through the map : @xmath22 which associates to each mould @xmath23 its corresponding word series @xmath24 .",
    "it is well - known @xcite that @xmath25 is a commutative hopf algebra , where @xmath26 is hoffman s quasi - shuffle product , recursively defined by @xmath27 ( here @xmath28 stands for the empty word ) and : @xmath29(\\bm\\omega'\\qshu \\bm\\omega'').\\ ] ] here @xmath30 and @xmath31 are letters in @xmath1 and @xmath32 are words in @xmath2 .",
    "the notation @xmath33 $ ] stands for the internal sum of the two letters in the commutative semigroup @xmath1 .",
    "the hopf algebra @xmath34 is @xmath35-graded by the weight defined by @xmath36 and : @xmath37 \\in \\omega\\ ] ] for a word @xmath38 of length @xmath39 .",
    "the mould product @xmath17 of @xcite is hence obtained by dualizing the deconcatenation coproduct @xmath40 , and thus reflects the noncommutative concatenation product in @xmath19 , namely : @xmath41    inspired by mould composition , i.e. , substitution of noncommutative formal series , we exhibit in this paper a second coproduct @xmath42 on @xmath34 which is coassociative and compatible with the quasi - shuffle product ( theorem [ coprod - c ] ) .",
    "it is _ internal _ in the sense that it respects each homogeneous component with respect to the weight grading , and it moreover endows hoffman s quasi - shuffle hopf algebra @xmath43 with the structure of comodule - hopf algebra @xcite over the bialgebra @xmath44 ( theorem [ comodule - bialgebra ] ) .",
    "surprisingly enough , dualizing the internal coproduct @xmath42 gives rise to a second composition product @xmath45 on moulds which does not coincide with the mould composition @xmath18 in general .",
    "more precisely the identity @xmath46 holds when the mould @xmath47 is _ symmetrel _",
    "@xcite , i.e. , when the identity @xmath48 holds for any words @xmath49 .",
    "the composition @xmath18 distributes over the mould product @xmath17 on the right , whereas the interplay between the product @xmath45 and the mould product @xmath17 is described by the comodule - hopf algebra structure .",
    "the paper is organized as follows . in section [",
    "sect : moules ] we recall some basics of j.   ecalle s mould calculus .",
    "section [ sect : wqsh ] is devoted to the notion of weak quasi - shuffles , which are surjective maps particularly useful to build up the internal coproduct in section [ sect : main ] .",
    "the main results therein are theorem [ coprod - c ] together with theorem [ comodule - bialgebra ] , which describe the comodule - bialgebra structure of the quasi - shuffle algebra endowed with both the deconcatenation coproduct @xmath40 and the internal coproduct @xmath42 .",
    "a link with contracting arborification @xcite is investigated in section [ arborification ] .",
    "in particular , we prove ( in theorem [ arbo - interne ] ) that contracting arborification changes the composition @xmath45 into an analogous composition @xmath45 of arborescent moulds , obtained by dualizing an internal coproduct which is a straightforward decorated version of the one given in @xcite .",
    "the analog of the mould composition @xmath18 for arborescent moulds was given in @xcite .",
    "its relation with composition @xmath18 of ordinary moulds via contracting arborification was precised in @xcite .",
    "* acknowledgements * : work partially supported by agence nationale de la recherche , projet carma nr-12-bs01 - 0017 .",
    "mould calculus evolved as part of ecalle s resurgence theory , and consists of a combinatorial setting which provides explicit as well as efficient formulas for studying local properties of dynamical systems . in this section",
    "we recall some basic facts on mould calculus .",
    "see references @xcite for more details .",
    "let @xmath1 be an alphabet endowed with a commutative semigroup law written additively .",
    "for example we can choose positive integers , i.e. , @xmath50 .",
    "a word @xmath3 consists of a string of letters @xmath51 , and will be denoted : @xmath52 the _ length _ of @xmath53 is its number @xmath54 of letters .",
    "the _ weight _ of the word @xmath3 is defined to be the sum of its letters in @xmath1 : @xmath55 \\in \\omega,\\ ] ] where the brackets indicate the internal sum in the commutative semigroup @xmath1 , in contrast with formal linear combinations which will be widely used in the sequel .",
    "the weight takes its values in @xmath56 .",
    "the unique word of weight zero is the empty word , denoted by @xmath28 , which happens to be of length zero , i.e. , @xmath57 .",
    "the concatenation of two words @xmath58 and @xmath59 is defined to be the word : @xmath60 of length @xmath61 .",
    "it defines a noncommutative , associative and unital product , with the unit being the empty word .",
    "we denote by @xmath2 the monoid of words on @xmath1 thus defined .",
    "let @xmath34 be the vector space ( over some base field @xmath6 ) spanned by the elements of @xmath2 .",
    "mould _ on the alphabet @xmath1 is a linear form @xmath23 on @xmath34 ( or , more generally , a linear map from @xmath34 into some unital commutative @xmath6-algebra @xmath8 ) .",
    "the evaluation of @xmath23 at a word @xmath3 will be denoted by @xmath62 . for two moulds",
    "@xmath63 we recall the definitions of _ mould multiplication _ and _ mould composition _ , respectively : @xmath64 recall that for @xmath65 the weight @xmath66 is a letter in @xmath1 .",
    "the basic algebraic properties of mould calculus can be stated as follows @xcite .",
    "[ mould - calculus ] mould multiplication and composition are both associative and noncommutative . composition distributes on the right over multiplication , namely : @xmath67 for any triple of moulds @xmath68 .",
    "the unit for mould multiplication is the mould @xmath69 defined by @xmath70 and @xmath71 for any nontrivial word @xmath72 .",
    "the unit for mould composition is the mould @xmath73 defined by @xmath74 for any letter @xmath75 and @xmath76 for @xmath77 or length @xmath78 .",
    "the unit properties for @xmath69 and @xmath73 as well as the noncommutativity of both products are immediate . whereas the associativity of the mould multiplication is easily checked ( it is nothing but the convolution product dual to the deconcatenation coproduct ) , the two other properties involving mould composition are better seen when the latter is interpreted as a substitution of alphabets .",
    "indeed , any @xmath8-valued mould @xmath23 gives rise to a _ word series _",
    "@xcite : @xmath79 which obviously determines the mould @xmath23 in return .",
    "the space of noncommutative formal series with variables in @xmath1 ( word series ) and with coefficients in @xmath8 is denoted by @xmath80 .",
    "the subspace of ( noncommutative ) polynomials is denoted @xmath81 .",
    "the homogeneous components of @xmath82 with respect to weight defined in are given for any letter @xmath83 by : @xmath84 this gives rise to a linear map @xmath85 , which uniquely extends by @xmath8-linearity , multiplicativity and completion , to a unital @xmath8-algebra endomorphism @xmath86 .",

    "in this section a new internal coproduct @xmath42 is introduced on @xmath34 , and it is shown to be compatible with hoffman s quasi - shuffle product . the quasi - shuffle hopf algebra @xmath43,where @xmath40 is the deconcatenation coproduct defined by equation below , is a comodule - hopf algebra over the bialgebra @xmath44 thus defined .",
    "we keep the notations of section [ sect : moules ] .",
    "the _ quasi - shuffle product _ of two words @xmath212 and @xmath213 in @xmath34 is defined by the formal sum : @xmath214 with @xmath215 \\in \\omega$ ] .",
    "note that the sum inside the brackets contains either one or two terms .",
    "the product is associative as well as commutative , and has the empty word @xmath28 as unit .",
    "a more immediate way of calculating quasi - shuffle products of words is given in terms of the equivalent recursive definition : @xmath216(\\omega_2\\cdots\\omega_p\\qshu\\omega_{p+2}\\cdots\\omega_{p+q}).\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] for example , @xmath217,\\\\      \\omega_1\\omega_{2}\\qshu\\omega_{3}=\\omega_3\\qshu\\omega_1\\omega_2      & = \\omega_1(\\omega_{2}\\qshu\\omega_{3 } ) + \\omega_{3}\\omega_1\\omega_{2 } + [ \\omega_1+\\omega_{3}]\\omega_{2}\\\\      & = \\omega_1\\omega_2\\omega_3+\\omega_1\\omega_3\\omega_2+\\omega_{3}\\omega_1\\omega_{2 } + \\omega_1[\\omega_2+\\omega_3]+ [ \\omega_1+\\omega_{3}]\\omega_{2}.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    let @xmath40 be the _ deconcatenation coproduct _ : @xmath218 it is well - known that @xmath43 is a commutative , noncocommutative , connected hopf algebra , graded by the weight defined in .",

    "let us check the third assertion for two length one words , i.e. , for the quasi - shuffle product of two letters @xmath221 : @xmath222 ) \\nonumber\\\\      & = & \\omega_1\\omega_2\\otimes(\\omega_1\\qshu \\omega_2 ) + [ \\omega_1+\\omega_2]\\otimes \\omega_1\\omega_2          + \\omega_2\\omega_1\\otimes ( \\omega_2\\qshu \\omega_1 )           + [ \\omega_2+\\omega_1]\\otimes \\omega_2\\omega_1 \\nonumber\\\\      & & \\quad + [ \\omega_1+\\omega_2]\\otimes[\\omega_1+\\omega_2 ] \\nonumber\\\\      & = & ( \\omega_1\\qshu \\omega_2)\\otimes(\\omega_1 \\qshu \\omega_2 ) \\label{group - like}\\\\      & = & \\gamma(\\omega_1)\\qshu\\gamma(\\omega_2 ) .",

    "the general case could certainly be handled by induction on the sum of the lengths of the two words involved , but we give here a direct proof based on the notion of weak quasi - shuffle defined in section [ sect : wqsh ] .",

    "the compatibility of @xmath42 with the quasi - shuffle product immediately implies that the mould composition of two symmetrel moulds is symmetrel .",

    "the two surjections @xmath327 and @xmath328 concatenate to give rise to a surjection @xmath329 with @xmath127 , hence both expressions match .    in the case",
    "@xmath330 , the quasi - shuffle hopf algebra @xmath43 admits a polynomial realization making it isomorphic to the hopf algebra @xmath331 of quasi - symmetric functions ( on some infinite alphabet @xmath191 ) .",
    "all results of this paragraph in this particular case could then have been deduced from the existence of an internal coproduct on @xmath331 .",
    "this coproduct is related to the tits product on set compositions of a given finite set ( @xcite , see also @xcite ) .",
    "the notion of arborification has been introduced by j.  ecalle in @xcite . a detailed presentation can be found in @xcite .",
    "see also @xcite for a hopf - algebraic presentation .",
    "arborescent mould _ is a collection @xmath332 , where @xmath333 is any rooted forest decorated by the alphabet @xmath1 .",
    "_ arborification _ , in its simple or contracting version , associates an arborescent mould to any ordinary mould in the sense of section [ sect : moules ] .",
    "we shall only consider the contracting version here .",
    "a rooted forest is a finite oriented graph @xmath333 without cycles , such that every vertex has at most one incoming edge .",
    "vertices with no incoming edge are called the roots , and it is easily seen that any nonempty forest has at least one root . a rooted forest with one single root is a _ rooted tree_. the set @xmath334 of vertices of @xmath333 is partially ordered : @xmath335 if and only if there exists an oriented path from one root to @xmath336 through @xmath337 . + an @xmath1-decorated rooted forest ( where @xmath1 is a given set ) is a pair @xmath338 where @xmath339 is a rooted forest and where @xmath340 is the decoration .",
    "let @xmath341 be the linear span of rooted forests decorated by @xmath1 .",
    "it is the free commutative algebra over the linear span @xmath342 of @xmath1-decorated rooted trees .",
    "it is a graded commutative hopf algebra @xcite , with the following coproduct : @xmath343 here @xmath334 stands for the set of vertices of @xmath333 , the restriction of the forest @xmath333 to a subset of @xmath334 is obtained by keeping only the edges joining two vertices in the subset , and @xmath344 means that for any @xmath345 and @xmath346 , one has @xmath347 .",
    "such a couple @xmath348 is called an _ admissible cut _",

    "let @xmath333 be a rooted forest decorated by @xmath1 .",
    "a _ covering subforest _ is a partition @xmath298 of the set @xmath334 of vertices of @xmath333 into connected components , which yields another @xmath1-decorated rooted forest still denoted by @xmath298 .",
    "the _ contracted forest _",
    "@xmath364 is obtained by shrinking each connected component of @xmath298 onto one vertex , which will be decorated by the sum of the decorations of all vertices of the connected component involved .",
    "the coproduct defined by : @xmath365 is coassociative , compatible with the product and internal , in the sense that if a forest @xmath333 has total weight @xmath294 , any covering subforest @xmath298 has also total weight @xmath296 , as well as the contracted forest @xmath364 .",
    "moreover , @xmath366 is a right comodule - hopf algebra over the bialgebra @xmath367 .",
    "this has been proved in @xcite without decorations , the adaptation to the decorated case is straightforward and left to the reader .",

    "recall @xcite that the free pre - lie algebra generated by @xmath1 is the linear span @xmath342 of @xmath1-decorated rooted trees .",
    "the pre - lie product @xmath461 of two trees is given by grafting the tree @xmath269 at every vertex of @xmath132 and taking the sum . in this particular case ,",
    "the @xmath457 product is known as the grossman  larson product on rooted forests @xcite .",

    ", the two compositions @xmath490 and @xmath491 coincide when @xmath47 is _ separative _ , i.e. when @xmath47 is a unital algebra morphism .",
    "[ mould - calculus - arbo ] both operations are associative , and composition distributes on the right over multiplication , namely : @xmath67 for any triple of arborescent moulds @xmath68 .",
    "the unit for the product is the mould @xmath69 defined by @xmath492 and @xmath493 for any nontrivial @xmath1-decorated rooted forest @xmath333 .",
    "the mould @xmath494 , defined by @xmath495 for any @xmath75 and @xmath496 for @xmath497 or @xmath333 forest with at least two vertices , is a unit on the right .",
    "the unit properties for @xmath69 and @xmath494 are immediate .",
    "note that @xmath494 can not be a unit on the left .",
    "indeed , for @xmath498 we have : @xmath499 which differs in general from @xmath500 .",
    "the associativity of the arborescent mould product directly comes from .",
    "associativity of arborescent composition can be checked directly : here @xmath501 means that @xmath298 is a covering subforest of @xmath333 , and @xmath502 means that the @xmath489 s are the connected components of @xmath298 . for three arborescent moulds @xmath96 and for any decorated forest @xmath333 we have : @xmath503 the distributivity property is also checked by a direct computation : @xmath504    there seems to be no available proof of proposition [ mould - calculus - arbo ] parallel to the one of proposition [ mould - calculus ] : in other words , associativity of the arborescent composition @xmath18 can not be directly derived from the associativity of @xmath475-series substitution @xcite , although the two results are closely related .",
    "composition of ordinary moulds does not correspond to composition of arborescent moulds via contracting arborification : for example , an easy computation gives : @xmath505}(n^{\\omega_1\\sqshu\\omega_2}-n^{\\omega_1}n^{\\omega_2}).\\ ] ] by theorem [ arbo - assoc ] , the identity @xmath506 however holds when @xmath47 is symmetrel .",

    "e.  hairer , c.  lubich , g.  wanner , _ geometric numerical integration _",
    "structure - preserving algorithms for ordinary differential equations , vol . * 31 * , springer series in computational mathematics .",
    "springer - verlag , berlin , 2002 .",
    "e.  vieillard - baron , _ simple and contracting arborification _ , in _ fa di bruno hopf algebras , dyson  schwinger equations and lie  butcher series _ , irma lectures in mathematics and theoretical physics * 21 * , k.  ebrahimi  fard and f.  fauvet eds . , europ .  math .",

  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> an internal coproduct is described , which is compatible with hoffman s quasi - shuffle product . </S>",
    "<S> hoffman s quasi - shuffle hopf algebra , with deconcatenation coproduct , is a comodule - hopf algebra over the bialgebra thus defined . </S>",
    "<S> the relation with ecalle s mould calculus , i.e. , mould composition and contracting arborification is precised .     </S>"
  ]
}
